Judaism: Judaism is an ethnic religion comprising a collective cultural, religious, and legal tradition.
Modern branches of Judaism such as Reform and Conservative adopt a more liberal approach.
Orthodox Judaism maintains that the Torah and Talmud are of divine origin.
Conservative Judaism teaches that Jewish law should adapt to the times.
In Judaism, the study of the Torah is considered a lifelong endeavor.
Reconstructionist Judaism does not see Jewish law as binding but as a guide.
Reform Judaism, called Liberal or Progressive Judaism, emphasizes individual autonomy.
Humanistic Judaism is a small non-theistic movement that focuses on Jewish culture.
Hasidic Judaism eventually became the way for Jews to reconnect with their spirituality.
Rabbinic Judaism claims that almost all interpretations of Jewish law come from the Oral Torah.
Christianity: Christianity is an Abrahamic monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus.
Christianity regards the biblical canon, the teachings of the Church Fathers, and creeds as authoritative.
Progressive Christianity represents a post-modern theological approach, emphasizing inclusivity.
Eastern Christianity comprises church families that developed in Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
Western Christianity is composed of the Latin Church and various Protestant churches.
Christian fundamentalism began in the late 19th century as a reaction to liberal theology.
Christian deism is one of several branches that focus on the teachings of Jesus without supernatural elements.
Christian Science is a set of beliefs and practices derived from the teachings of Mary Baker Eddy.
Nondenominational Christianity consists of churches that do not align with any specific Christian tradition.
Christian mysticism refers to mystical practices and beliefs within the Christian tradition.
Islam: Islam teaches that God is merciful, all-powerful, and unique.
Sunni Islam is sometimes referred to as orthodox Islam and follows the practices of the Prophet Muhammad.
Shia Islam is based on Muhammad's teachings and the leadership of his family.
Islam is the fastest-growing major religion in the world.
In Islam, God is beyond all comprehension but is described in the Quran through 99 names.
Mystical traditions in Islam place these qualities as central to understanding God.
Islamic law would not be the same without the influence of classical scholars.
Shia Islam embodies a completely independent system of interpretation and jurisprudence.
Many traditional scholars saw Sunni Islam in terms of following the Sunnah (traditions of the Prophet).
Islamic hygienic practices mainly fall into personal cleanliness, such as ritual washing before prayer.
Hinduism: Hinduism is one of the world's oldest religious traditions, with a diverse range of beliefs.
Hindu philosophy refers to the various philosophical traditions that emerged in ancient India.
Hindu reform movements aim to reinterpret traditional practices in light of modern values.
Balinese Hinduism is the form of Hinduism practiced by the majority of the population in Bali, Indonesia.
The orthodox schools of Hindu philosophy have historically emphasized different interpretations of the Vedas.
Hinduism encompasses a variety of traditions, rituals, and spiritual paths.
Hindu denominations are traditions within Hinduism that have different interpretations of scriptures.
Hindu philosophy recognizes many types of Yoga, which are paths to spiritual realization.
Hinduism in Indonesia had a pantheon of deities before merging with local animistic beliefs.
Estimates of Hinduism by country reflect the global diversity of its adherents.
Buddhism: Buddhism is the world's fourth-largest religion, teaching the path to enlightenment through meditation and ethics.
Theravada Buddhism has a widespread following in Southeast Asia.
Mahyna Buddhism holds that these other Buddhas reside in different universes.
Tibetan Buddhism, which preserves the Vajrayana tradition, is a form of Mahayana Buddhism.
Zen Buddhism focuses on meditation practice as a means to attain direct insight into the nature of existence.
In Buddhism, dukkha is one of the Four Noble Truths, referring to the inherent suffering in life.
Pure Land Buddhism is built on the belief in the compassionate power of the Buddha Amitābha.
In early Buddhism, it was commonly believed that one could reach enlightenment through self-discipline.
Tibetan Buddhism claims to teach methods for achieving spiritual liberation.
Insight in Mahāyāna Buddhism also includes the realization of the emptiness of all phenomena.
Sikhism: Sikhism is a monotheistic religion that originated in the Punjab region of India in the 15th century.
Sikhism stresses kirat karō: that is, living an honest life while sharing with others.
Adherents of Sikhism are known as Sikhs, and they follow the teachings of Guru Nanak.
In Sikhism, the concept of 'God' is described as formless and timeless.
Sikhism considers 'an attack on dharam' as a justification for the use of force.
The traditions and philosophy of Sikhism were shaped by ten successive Sikh Gurus.
Sikhism rejects claims that any religion has a monopoly on absolute truth.
The word 'Guru' in Sikhism also refers to God, as an ultimate guide.
Sikhism developed while the region was experiencing significant political and religious upheaval.
God in Sikhism has no gender, and both men and women can attain liberation.
Atheism: Atheism is, in the broadest sense, the absence of belief in the existence of deities.
Implicit atheism is 'the absence of belief in gods without a conscious rejection.'
Nonbelievers contend that atheism is a position that lacks any belief in supernatural beings.
Positive atheism is the explicit affirmation that gods do not exist.
In an even narrower sense, atheism is specifically the belief that there is no God.
The term atheism was derived from the Greek word atheos, meaning 'without god.'
Atheism has sometimes been defined to include agnosticism.
Metaphysical atheism may be either materialistic or idealistic in nature.
Atheism is often contrasted with theism, which is the belief in one or more deities.
State atheism emerged in the 20th century in several communist countries.
